title: How to Freeze Homemade Gnocchi

steps.headline: Sprinkle flour on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
steps.description: Cover a baking sheet with parchment paper so the gnocchi dough does not get stuck. Pour enough flour to coat the baking tray, but not so much that it starts to form piles. This also helps prevent the gnocchi from sticking to the tray.

steps.headline: Space uncooked gnocchi evenly on the tray.
steps.description: Uncooked gnocchi freezes and stores best. The gnocchi should not be stacked or crowded on the tray, or else they may stick together. Leave a space the size of 1 piece of gnocchi between each dumpling. To prevent the gnocchi from sticking together, dust the dough with flour before you let them dry.

steps.headline: Let the gnocchi dry at room temperature for 45 minutes.
steps.description: Gnocchi that are directly frozen after they've been made may feather apart when you try to cook them. By keeping the gnocchi at room temperature for at least 45 minutes, you solidify the dumplings more. Gnocchi can be dried for up to 4 hours at room temperature. To protect your gnocchi from contamination, you can cover them with a tea towel.

steps.headline: Place the tray in the freezer for 3 hours.
steps.description: Keep the tray level when you place it in the freezer so the gnocchi doesn't shift or move while they freeze. It takes about 3 hours for gnocchi to freeze entirely through.

steps.headline: Transfer the frozen gnocchi into a resealable bag.
steps.description: Once the gnocchi has frozen entirely through, gather them from the tray and transfer them to a resealable plastic bag or container. If you want to ensure they do not freeze together, freeze the gnocchi in a single layer. Weigh out 125 grams (4.4 oz) of gnocchi to place in separate bags for single servings that are easy to prepare. If you store the gnocchi in a plastic container, use pieces of parchment paper to separate the layers of gnocchi.

steps.headline: Store the gnocchi for up to 2 months.
steps.description: When you freeze your gnocchi, label them with the date as a reminder of when you made them. Gnocchi can be cooked directly out of the freezer once you're ready to use them.

steps.headline: Boil 6 quarts (5.68 L) of salted water in a pot.
steps.description: Keep the pot over medium-high heat on the stove. Salt your water before you add the gnocchi to help season them and make your water boil faster. Using more water will help keep it at a boil once you add the gnocchi and prevent them from sticking together.

steps.headline: Add the gnocchi to the water directly from the freezer.
steps.description: There is no need to thaw out gnocchi before you cook them, but they will take slightly longer to cook than fresh. When you remove the gnocchi from the freezer, shake off any excess flour that may be stuck to them.

steps.headline: Stir the gnocchi until they float, or about 6 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the water boiling so the gnocchi cooks all the way through. Once the gnocchi is finished, they will float to the top of the water. Gnocchi should have a soft, fluffy consistency once they are cooked. Cover the pots with lids to keep the heat at a consistent level.

steps.headline: Drain the water and serve the gnocchi.
steps.description: Once all the water is removed, add your favorite sauce to the gnocchi. Top them with grated cheese and herbs, such as basil or oregano, as a finishing touch. Gnocchi tastes great with pesto or tomato sauce, but tastes just as good coated in melted butter.

text: Storing Uncooked Gnocchi Sprinkle flour on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Cover a baking sheet with parchment paper so the gnocchi dough does not get stuck. Pour enough flour to coat the baking tray, but not so much that it starts to form piles. This also helps prevent the gnocchi from sticking to the tray. Space uncooked gnocchi evenly on the tray. Uncooked gnocchi freezes and stores best. The gnocchi should not be stacked or crowded on the tray, or else they may stick together. Leave a space the size of 1 piece of gnocchi between each dumpling. To prevent the gnocchi from sticking together, dust the dough with flour before you let them dry. Let the gnocchi dry at room temperature for 45 minutes. Gnocchi that are directly frozen after they've been made may feather apart when you try to cook them. By keeping the gnocchi at room temperature for at least 45 minutes, you solidify the dumplings more. Gnocchi can be dried for up to 4 hours at room temperature. To protect your gnocchi from contamination, you can cover them with a tea towel. Place the tray in the freezer for 3 hours. Keep the tray level when you place it in the freezer so the gnocchi doesn't shift or move while they freeze. It takes about 3 hours for gnocchi to freeze entirely through. Transfer the frozen gnocchi into a resealable bag. Once the gnocchi has frozen entirely through, gather them from the tray and transfer them to a resealable plastic bag or container. If you want to ensure they do not freeze together, freeze the gnocchi in a single layer. Weigh out 125 grams (4.4 oz) of gnocchi to place in separate bags for single servings that are easy to prepare. If you store the gnocchi in a plastic container, use pieces of parchment paper to separate the layers of gnocchi. Store the gnocchi for up to 2 months. When you freeze your gnocchi, label them with the date as a reminder of when you made them. Gnocchi can be cooked directly out of the freezer once you're ready to use them. Cooking Frozen Gnocchi Boil 6 quarts (5.68 L) of salted water in a pot. Keep the pot over medium-high heat on the stove. Salt your water before you add the gnocchi to help season them and make your water boil faster. Using more water will help keep it at a boil once you add the gnocchi and prevent them from sticking together. Add the gnocchi to the water directly from the freezer. There is no need to thaw out gnocchi before you cook them, but they will take slightly longer to cook than fresh. When you remove the gnocchi from the freezer, shake off any excess flour that may be stuck to them. Stir the gnocchi until they float, or about 6 minutes. Keep the water boiling so the gnocchi cooks all the way through. Once the gnocchi is finished, they will float to the top of the water. Gnocchi should have a soft, fluffy consistency once they are cooked. Cover the pots with lids to keep the heat at a consistent level. Drain the water and serve the gnocchi. Once all the water is removed, add your favorite sauce to the gnocchi. Top them with grated cheese and herbs, such as basil or oregano, as a finishing touch. Gnocchi tastes great with pesto or tomato sauce, but tastes just as good coated in melted butter.

Cover a baking sheet with parchment paper so the gnocchi dough does not get stuck.
Pour enough flour to coat the baking tray, but not so much that it starts to form piles.
This also helps prevent the gnocchi from sticking to the tray.
Space uncooked gnocchi evenly on the tray.

The gnocchi should not be stacked or crowded on the tray, or else they may stick together.

To prevent the gnocchi from sticking together, dust the dough with flour before you let them dry.
Let the gnocchi dry at room temperature for 45 minutes.
Gnocchi that are directly frozen after they've been made may feather apart when you try to cook them.
By keeping the gnocchi at room temperature for at least 45 minutes, you solidify the dumplings more.
Gnocchi can be dried for up to 4 hours at room temperature.
To protect your gnocchi from contamination, you can cover them with a tea towel.
Place the tray in the freezer for 3 hours.
Keep the tray level when you place it in the freezer so the gnocchi doesn't shift or move while they freeze.
It takes about 3 hours for gnocchi to freeze entirely through.
Transfer the frozen gnocchi into a resealable bag.
Once the gnocchi has frozen entirely through, gather them from the tray and transfer them to a resealable plastic bag or container.
If you want to ensure they do not freeze together, freeze the gnocchi in a single layer.

If you store the gnocchi in a plastic container, use pieces of parchment paper to separate the layers of gnocchi.
Store the gnocchi for up to 2 months.
When you freeze your gnocchi, label them with the date as a reminder of when you made them.
Gnocchi can be cooked directly out of the freezer once you're ready to use them.
Cooking Frozen Gnocchi Boil 6 quarts (5.68 L) of salted water in a pot.
Keep the pot over medium-high heat on the stove.
Salt your water before you add the gnocchi to help season them and make your water boil faster.
Using more water will help keep it at a boil once you add the gnocchi and prevent them from sticking together.
Add the gnocchi to the water directly from the freezer.
There is no need to thaw out gnocchi before you cook them, but they will take slightly longer to cook than fresh.
When you remove the gnocchi from the freezer, shake off any excess flour that may be stuck to them.
Stir the gnocchi until they float, or about 6 minutes.
Keep the water boiling so the gnocchi cooks all the way through.
Once the gnocchi is finished, they will float to the top of the water.
Gnocchi should have a soft, fluffy consistency once they are cooked.
Cover the pots with lids to keep the heat at a consistent level.
Drain the water and serve the gnocchi.
Once all the water is removed, add your favorite sauce to the gnocchi.
Top them with grated cheese and herbs, such as basil or oregano, as a finishing touch.
Gnocchi tastes great with pesto or tomato sauce, but tastes just as good coated in melted butter.
